title: Boris Johnson remains defiant after MPs back Brexit deal delay
text:
Mr Johnson must ask for an extension (Picture: Sky News)

Brexit must be delayed after MPs voted in favour of an amendment designed to give a cast-iron guarantee against no-deal.

In a humiliating move, Boris Johnson must now write to the EU to ask for an extension until January 31.

However immediately after he lost the vote, the PM again threatened not to comply.

MPs have spent all day taking part in a historic House of Commons sitting to vote on the new deal Mr Johnson agreed with EU leaders.

There were doubts, however, that it could all be completed before the October 31 deadline.

Former Tory minister Sir Oliver Letwin put down an amendment to force all the legal frameworks to be in place to stop the UK accidentally crashing out without a deal in two weeks’ time.

That motion was approved by 322 MPs – helped by the Labour party and Mr Johnson’s former DUP allies.

There were 306 against it – a majority of 16.

It means that at midnight tonight the Benn Act comes into force which makes no-deal illegal and requires Mr Johnson to beg for an extra three months.

The PM had told MPs earlier in the day that any extension would be ‘pointless, expensive and deeply corrosive of public trust.’

Speaking after the Letwin vote, Mr Johnson roared: ‘I continue in the very strong belief that the best thing for the UK, and for the whole of Europe is for us to leave with this new deal on October 31.

‘And to anticipate the questions that are coming from the benches opposite, I will not negotiate a delay with the EU.’

This is breaking and will be updated.
